name: Guru Gobind Singh Ji
excerpt: Guru Gobind Singh Ji, the tenth Sikh Guru, redefined Sikhism with his unmatched courage, visionary leadership, and prolific poetry. Founder of the Khalsa, compiler of the Dasam Granth, and sanctifier of the Guru Granth Sahib as the eternal Guru, he led Sikhs through persecution and loss. His legacy unites valor, sacrifice, equality, and spiritual resolve.

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Born as Gobind Rai on 22 December 1666 in Patna Sahib, Bihar, Guru Gobind Singh Ji spent his early years immersed in spiritual learning and martial training. After his father Guru Tegh Bahadur Ji's martyrdom, he was installed as the tenth Guru at age nine, shaping him for a life of leadership and sacrifice.[1][3][20]

biographySections.label: Founding of Khalsa
biographySections.value: On Vaisakhi 1699 at Anandpur Sahib, Guru Gobind Singh Ji dramatically created the Khalsa, baptizing the Panj Pyare and initiating men and women of all castes into a new spiritual order dedicated to righteousness, equality, and defense of the oppressed.[1][6][9]

biographySections.label: Scripture and Literary Contributions
biographySections.value: A philosopher and poet, Guru Gobind Singh Ji composed the Dasam Granth and sanctified the Guru Granth Sahib as the Sikhs’ eternal Guru, binding the community to a spiritual anchor for all time. His works—Jap Sahib, Jaap, Akal Ustat—embody devotion, valor, and oneness with the Divine.[2][13]

biographySections.label: Family Sacrifice and Battles
biographySections.value: Guru Ji’s life was marked by immense personal sacrifice. All his four sons attained martyrdom—two in battle at Chamkaur, two bricked alive at Sirhind. He personally led Sikhs in major battles at Bhangani, Anandpur, Chamkaur, and Muktsar; always upholding the principles of just war (dharamyudh) and faith against tyranny.[2][5][9]

biographySections.label: Final Years and Legacy
biographySections.value: In his last years, Guru Gobind Singh Ji survived many assassination attempts and finally attained martyrdom on 7 October 1708 at Nanded. Before passing, he declared that henceforth the Guru Granth Sahib would be the eternal Guru, abolishing the tradition of personal Gurus and inaugurating a new era for the Sikh faith.[1][9]

spiritualLegacy.description: Guru Gobind Singh Ji’s divine inspiration set Sikhism on its path of valor, spiritual sovereignty, and the defense of justice. His creation of the Khalsa established the Sikh identity as inseparably linked to equality, sacrifice, compassion, and devotion.
keyContributions: Instituted the Khalsa Panth and the Five Ks
Sanctified Guru Granth Sahib as the eternal Guru
Composed the Dasam Granth, inspiring prayer, chivalry, and resilience
Elevated Sikh martial and spiritual disciplines
Unified Sikhs beyond distinctions, empowering women and lower castes

modernRelevance.description: Guru Gobind Singh Ji’s message stands for universal human rights, social justice, and resistance to tyranny. The Khalsa remains a living example of fearlessness, service, and global humanitarianism.
contemporaryImpact: Khalsa tradition inspires humanitarian, anti-oppression, and equality movements
His poetry and codes guide modern Sikh ritual and philosophy
Gurdwaras and Sikh diaspora model his ideals of seva (service) and courage in times of crisis

achievements.title: Founded Khalsa Panth
achievements.description: Created a new order bound by a distinctive spiritual and martial identity, dedicated to justice and faith.

achievements.title: Sanctified Eternal Guru
achievements.description: Declared Guru Granth Sahib as the perpetual spiritual guide for all Sikhs.

achievements.title: Composed the Dasam Granth
achievements.description: Compiled poems, prayers, and philosophical works still foundational to Sikh liturgy and practice.

achievements.title: Led Major Defensive Battles
achievements.description: Fought at Bhangani, Anandpur, Chamkaur, Muktsar; symbolizing righteous resistance to cruelty.

achievements.title: Personal Sacrifice
achievements.description: Endured loss of all four sons (Chaar Sahibzaade) who were martyred for faith and justice.

quotes.original: ਦੇਹ ਸੀਵ ਗੁਰ ਕੀ ਭਗਤਿ ਕਰੀਜੈ। ਇਉ ਰਹੈ ਦੇਹੀ ਭਾਇ ਨ ਕੀਜੈ।
quotes.transliteration: Deh sīv gur kī bhagat karījai. Iu rahai dehī bhāi na kījai.
quotes.translation: Sew your body with devotion to the Guru; do not be attached to this body as your own.

quotes.original: ਚਿੱਠੀ ਲਿਖੀ ਸਿਰ ਮੁੜੈ ਨਾਉ। ਦੀਨ ਦੁਨਿਆ ਰਖਿਆ ਧਰਮ ਕਾ ਨਾਉ॥
quotes.transliteration: Chitthi likhi sir murhai nāu. Deen duniyā rakhiā dharam kā nāu.
quotes.translation: I have signed this letter with my decapitated head; upholding dharma in both worlds.
quotes.context: On spiritual courage in the Zafarnama to Aurangzeb

quotes.original: ਮਿਤ੍ਰ ਪਿਆਰੇ ਨੂੰ ਹਾਲ ਮੁਰੀਦਾਂ ਦਾ ਕਹਿਣਾ
quotes.transliteration: Mitr piyāre nū haal mureedān dā kehna
quotes.translation: Tell the Beloved Friend of the plight of His disciples.
quotes.context: Written after the martyrdom of his sons, expressing spiritual longing amid suffering

relatedPersonalities.name: Baba Ajit Singh Ji, Baba Jujhar Singh Ji, Baba Zorawar Singh Ji, Baba Fateh Singh Ji

historicalContext.politicalSituation: Widespread persecution of non-Muslims in the Mughal Empire, intense repression of the Sikh and Hindu communities, and centralization of power under Aurangzeb.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Rigid caste divides, religious intolerance, and institutional violence necessitated a powerful, unified Sikh community ready to defend dharma and equality.
historicalContext.significance: Guru Gobind Singh Ji’s leadership transformed Sikhism into a distinctly sovereign, martial, and egalitarian faith with enduring identity and resilience.
